summary: Email correspondence between US Department of Justice officials and UK Crown Prosecution Service regarding extradition law, specifically discussing whether a defendant's preemptive consent to extradition given in the US would be binding in UK courts. The discussion centers on a UK citizen detained in the US seeking bail.

persons.name: Amanda J Chadwick
persons.context: US Department of Justice Attaché at the United States Embassy in London, involved in extradition discussions with UK Crown Prosecution Service.

persons.name: Anne-Marie Kundert
persons.context: Head of the Extradition Unit in the International Justice and Organised Crime Division of the UK Crown Prosecution Service, providing legal analysis on extradition consent.

persons.name: Punam Chopra
persons.context: Crown Prosecution Service official copied on extradition discussion emails, marked as sensitive recipient.

connections.description: US DOJ official consulting with UK CPS extradition unit head on legal questions regarding extradition consent.
Both work for the UK Crown Prosecution Service, with Chopra copied on Kundert's legal analysis emails.

events.title: Extradition Legal Analysis Provided
events.description: Anne-Marie Kundert provides detailed legal analysis on UK extradition law, explaining that consent given to US authorities is not binding on UK courts.

events.title: Extradition Draft Section Shared
events.description: US Attorney's Office shares draft extradition section with UK contact for review and feedback.

keyFacts: UK extradition law requires consent to be given irrevocably in writing to the UK court under Section 72(8) of the Extradition Act 2003, not to US authorities.
A defendant's prophylactic 'consent to be extradited' given in the US would not be binding on a UK court or the defendant (referred to as 'RP' - requested person).
The Crown Prosecution Service indicates that if a defendant returns to the UK and reneges on bail conditions, this would lead to an extradition request and affect bail decisions.
The discussion involves a UK citizen detained in the US facing US charges who is seeking bail and wants to use consent to extradition as proof they are not a flight risk.
Consent to extradition in the UK is irrevocable and not appealable, unlike a guilty plea which can be withdrawn.
